title: R40474
content: This report examines recent laws and congressional proposals regarding gun regulation in the District of Columbia. Key statutes and bills include federal provisions like the National Firearms Act and Gun Control Act, the D.C. Firearms Control Regulation Act, the Second Amendment Enforcement Act (H.R. 645), and the District's Firearms Control Amendment Act and Inoperable Pistol Amendment Act. Congressional proposals often coincide with discussions on voting rights for the District. The report analyzes recent laws and congressional proposals on gun regulation in the District of Columbia, focusing on Title II of S. 160 from the 111th Congress and H.R. 645 from the 112th Congress. It discusses the impact of these proposals on DC firearms laws post the Supreme Court's decision in District of Columbia v. Heller. After the Supreme Court's decision in District of Columbia v. Heller, congressional activity on DC firearms laws focused on the Second Amendment's protection of an individual's right to possess a firearm for self-defense within the home. The decision in Heller invalidated three provisions of the District's Firearms Control Regulation Act. After the Supreme Court's decision in District of Columbia v. Heller, the DC Council enacted emergency legislation to comply with the ruling, amending the city's gun laws temporarily. This attempt was met with criticism for not fully complying with the Heller decision. The Firearms Control Emergency Amendment Act of 2008 was met with criticism for not fully complying with the Heller decision. In response, H.R. 6691, the Second Amendment Enforcement Act, was introduced in Congress but did not become law. In the 111th Congress, Senator John Ensign introduced S.Amdt. 575 to S. 160, which became Title II of S. 160. Despite Senate approval, movement on the legislation was stalled. The DC Council passed emergency legislation until permanent legislation could take effect, incorporating language from the emergency acts. The Firearms Control Amendment Act of 2008 (FCAA) and the Inoperable Pistol Amendment Act of 2008 (IPAA) were passed by the DC Council and transmitted to Congress for approval. These acts amended firearms provisions in the DC Code and imposed new restrictions on firearm regulation and ownership. The legislation was challenged but upheld in court. Congressional legislation, H.R. 645, also aimed to impact DC's gun laws. Congress passed H.R. 645 to amend firearms provisions in the DC Code, limiting the District's ability to regulate firearm possession and repealing the registration scheme. The District of Columbia can amend laws passed by Congress on firearms regulations under the Home Rule Act, but Congress can still impose limits on its legislative authority. This restriction aims to prevent the authority from prohibiting or burdening individuals from acquiring, possessing, transporting, or using firearms for lawful purposes. The proposed language in H.R. 645 emphasizes that the District of Columbia cannot enact laws that restrict private ownership or use of firearms.
